Layout

TK

Doc bounds

TK

Doc stripe

TK

Flex row

Arranges content in rows using display: flex.

The .flexrow class is applied to a wrapping element.

Direct children of .flexrow are flex children, and require either a .flexrow-item--grow or .flexrow-item--shirnk class.

The flex children in flexrow do not have a flex-basis set; a basis is not required for most common layout tasks.

Includes table-cell fallback for IE8.

Examples:

Item 1
Item 2
Item 3
Item 4
<div class="flexrow">
    <div class="_DOC-SHADE flexrow-item--grow flexrow-item--gutterLeft">Item 1</div>
    <div class="_DOC-SHADE flexrow-item--shrink">Item 2</div>
    <div class="_DOC-SHADE flexrow-item--shrink">Item 3</div>
    <div class="_DOC-SHADE flexrow-item--grow">Item 4</div>
</div>
Item 1
Item 2
Item 3
<div class="flexrow">
    <div class="_DOC-SHADE flexrow-item--shrink flexrow-item--gutterBoth">Item 1</div>
    <div class="_DOC-SHADE flexrow-item--grow">Item 2</div>
    <div class="_DOC-SHADE flexrow-item--shrink">Item 3</div>
</div>
Item 1
Item 2
Item 3
<div class="flexrow flexrow--flexEnd">
    <div class="_DOC-SHADE flexrow-item--shrink flexrow-item--gutterBoth">Item 1</div>
    <div class="_DOC-SHADE flexrow-item--shrink flexrow-item--gutterBoth">Item 2</div>
    <div class="_DOC-SHADE flexrow-item--shrink flexrow-item--gutterBoth">Item 3</div>
</div>
Item 1
Item 2
Item 3
Item 4
<div class="flexrow flexrow--spaceBetween flexrow--reverse">
    <div class="_DOC-SHADE flexrow-item--shrink">Item 1</div>
    <div class="_DOC-SHADE flexrow-item--shrink">Item 2</div>
    <div class="_DOC-SHADE flexrow-item--shrink">Item 3</div>
    <div class="_DOC-SHADE flexrow-item--shrink">Item 4</div>
</div>

flexrow-item variants

A class of .flexrow-item--shirnk or .flexrow-item--grow on flexrow children is required. The following classes are optional variants:

Class Description
.flexrow-item--gutterRight adds padding-right to item
.flexrow-item--gutterLeft adds padding-left to item
.flexrow-item--gutterBoth adds padding-both sides of item

flexrow variants

A class of .flexrow is required on the flexrow parent. The following classes are optional variants:

Class Description
.flexrow--reverse reverses row order
.flexrow--flexEnd justifies content to flex-end
.flexrow--center justifies content to center
.flexrow--spaceBetween justifies content to spaceBetween
.flexrow--spaceAround justifies content to spaceAround
.flexrow--wrapAt[breakpoint] allows wrapping at a given breakpoint (Small, Medium, Large)

Typesetting

TK - notes about UI text vs. body text

Heading 1 Display

Heading 1

Heading 2

Heading 3

Heading 4

Heading 5
Heading 6

Body text

Fake heading

Hint text

Small text

Caption text

<h1 class="text--display">Heading 1 Display</h1>
<h1>Heading 1</h1>
<h2>Heading 2</h2>
<h3>Heading 3</h3>
<h4>Heading 4</h4>
<h5>Heading 5</h5>
<h6>Heading 6</h6>
<p>Body text</p>
<p class="text--heading">Fake heading</p>
<p class="text--hint">Hint text</p>
<p class="text--small">Small text</p>
<p class="text--caption">Caption text</p>

Body/primary text

This is default body text, inheritied from type styles applied to <body>

<p>This is default body text, inheritied from type styles applied to &lt;body&gt;</p>

Caption text

I'm captioning all the things

<p class="text--caption">I'm captioning all the things</p>

Display text

Display text for header hero elements.

The hero gotham deserves

<h1 class="text--display">The hero gotham deserves</h1>

Hint text

This is hint text

<p class="text--hint">This is hint text</p>

Inverted text

Apply the inverted class to a container with a dark background color or photo to flip all text elements to inveted colors.

This is default body text, inheritied from type styles applied to <body>

<div style="background: #353E48;" class="inverted">
    <p>This is default body text, inheritied from type styles applied to &lt;body&gt;</p>
</div>

Running text

By default, paragraphs and headings are not styled with any bottom spacing. Links are not blue by default, as the most common case on Meetup will be block-level anchors with large touch targets.

However, there will be instaces where you want the blue links and properly spaced paragraphs of running text (ie. event descriptions).

The robot is partially dressed in waterproof surgical garb.

"Bruce Springsteen" is a terrible name for a cat.

The robot is partially dressed in waterproof surgical garb.

"Bruce Springsteen" is a terrible name for a cat.

<p>The robot is partially dressed in waterproof surgical garb.</p>
<p>"Bruce Springsteen" is a terrible name for a <a href="#">cat</a>.</p>

<hr style="margin: 8px;" /> <!-- lol, hr -->

<div class="runningText">
    <p>The robot is partially dressed in waterproof surgical garb.</p>
    <p>"Bruce Springsteen" is a terrible name for a <a href="#">cat</a>.</p>
</div>

Link color

You can always force an anchor to apply a linky blue color by applying the .link class.

Let's force this link to be blue

<p>Let's force this <a class="link" href="#">link</a> to be blue</p>

Secondary text

Secondary text is secondary

<p class="text--secondary">Secondary text is secondary</p>

Small text

Small text is small

<p class="text--small">Small text is small</p>
